author: Staff Reporter
text:
233 students received certificates at College of Nursing, CMC

Former dean and head of School of Dentistry, University of Adelaide, South Australia Kaye Frances Roberts-Thomson stressed the need for nursing graduates to make the most of opportunities that arise to be learners throughout their career.

Delivering the graduation address at the College of Nursing, Christian Medical College (CMC), Vellore, on Tuesday, Dr. Thomson said carrying out what has been taught in practice whether in a community or hospital was very important.

“But it is also critical that the knowledge you have gained up to now will not be adequate for you in 10 years since the knowledge and skills in health care is constantly changing. So make the most of opportunities that arise to be learner throughout your career,” she said.

Dr. Thomson urged the graduates to practice compassion and justice.

“Compassion should be the prime factor in your interaction with patients. Justice is about caring for our social environment,” she added.

A total of 233 students received the certificates during the graduation day – 198 undergraduates,

28 post graduates and seven post diplomas in nursing from the CMC’s College of Nursing.

Sunil Chandy, director of CMC, Selva Titus Chacko, dean, College of Nursing, Vinitha Ravindran, deputy dean and Manoranjitham, registrar, were present, according to a press release.

title: Nursing graduates of CMC urged to keep learning
